Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Selected site in a large wind pillow along the treeline where skiers would be tempted to travel. A small storm with light precipitation and moderate northwesterly winds had just set in as we picked our site. Winds were blowing perpendicular to the slope. Observed layers in the upper 10 cm were thin and numerous, like a deli sandwich, indicating continuous wind loading from the same direction (cross-loading).

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: NSF buried near top of snowpack resulting in minimal collapsing during ECT. Density change at 103cm resulted in non propagating irregular failure during ECT. Rather Stable Snow at this time

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ran out of time to do more stability tests, but several shovel shear tests failed on the 194-195cm layer of facets below the crust.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very light snowfall at times during the snowpit profile, on and off fog, almost no wind Wind loading from the storm from the day before, none during the day of the test The compression test shows relatively stable snowpack conditions on slopes of similar steepness and aspect, despite a lot of spontaneous and human triggered avalanches from the day before. The likely reason for this is that the snow has had some time to settle and create a stronger bond with the sugary layer below it. However, the sugary layer below still needs to be watched as at some point later in the season it can be "triggered" and create large avalanches. The new snow - about 50cm - does not slide on the sugary layer below it during the test. Instead, it breaks up starting from about CT25 to the end of the test at CT30.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Saddle Horn chutes avalanched in Dec. leaving very shallow HS. After many weaks without snow almost the entire pack in this chute is very weak. Just getting weaker. DL slides in consequential terrain are getting large enough to be a hazard.

We snowmobiled slope;
Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Loc: Behind Schweitzer Chair 1 triple. Low density 5 cm new snow overnight (2/2 - 2/3). Light-Moderate W wind transport. @ 26.5 cm is smooth planar surface and finding some/few FC equal to or less than 1 mm. Jan 12th rain (@26 cm) is still bridging. Some mixed grain forms @ 26.5-35 cm, appears to be trending toward RG's. Top ~10 cm Not a cohesive slab yet but keep eyes on Jan 30th SH.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cold day. 4 below at the car when we left and 4 below at the car when we got back. Only about 30 cm new snow total in the past 3 weeks, with 15 cm of that in the past 2 weeks. Pathetic! We need snow!

First opening below Access Road south of Teton Pass Summit. Wind sheltered zone that sees very little foot traffic. Weak upper snowpack! Profile compared well with one generated by Propagation Labs probe (see attached photo). Basal facets would need significant loading before reactivation.

Nokkuð stöðug snjóþekjan á svæðinu, sjáanleg hengjubrot hér og þar í giljum enda einu staðirnir sem var snjór þar sem gras og grjót kom ekki upp úr. Varhugaverðar hengjur og aðstæður í giljunum þar sem skafsnjór síðastliðinn sólahring er ekki með mikla viðloðun við eldri snjóalög. Stöðuleika athugun gaf ECTN26@83 sem gaf sig á gömlu mjög grófkornuðu lagi.
Hasty pit and did not gather all data for layers.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. Kauttaaltaan ohut lumipeite. Pirunkurun vasemmalla puolella (alhaalta katsoen) oleva ensimmäinen aukea harjanteen takana. Toinen nopea pit Pirunkurun laitaan, jossa lumi pehmeää pohjaan saakka. Humahteli. Testit molemmissa epävarmoja kivirakasta johtuen. Ei merkattu. Samat kerrokset kuitenkin erottuu, jotka ovat pohjoispuolellakin.
Obj: Bedöm drevsnöflak
Pit dug on SW. aspect of Blueberry Knoll, 100ft below ridgetop adjacent to stunted hemlock trees

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surface-Widespread SH 5-8 mm. Slight Sun crusts in specific loc. Only able to find trace SH @ 17cm after CT result. ECT X due to 1/12 rain bridge, but Moderate hand shear after of ECT column @ 17 cm. Distinct change in hand hardness @ 170-170.5, not confident in gain form here.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was dug adjacent to an avalanche on the standard route to the Chessman snow course. This slope was heavily wind loaded, all snow from the windward side had been transported onto the leeward slope. Avalanche was 200 ft across, 1-2.5 feet deep, and ran 40-50 feet.
Cloud layer at 7600-~9300ft

Pit in a forested clearing above Tagert hut that is representative of maximum snow depth. Amazing to have this HS here with almost 2m of P hard slab! Dug a very deep hole to look at depth hoar which is rounding. In areas of this depth might have some spring wet slab concerns on this DH layer if it survives the weight.

moraine on lower simba

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surprisingly shallow snow pack on this tour. Depth hoar is well preserved here and faceting is happening in these thin areas.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Quick Profile, most interested in temp gradient / tests. - Approaching isothermic w/ very shallow gradient - Only had analogue thermometer, hence low resolution on temp profile. - Deep Tap Test / Compression test done(2x each) no repeatable results

Nästan P resultat down 47, men vill ej glida, svårt att rubba kolumnen för hand.
Inte optimal läsida men helt okej för att få ut information om dem senaste blidorna.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: last storm was in between Christmas and years 21
thin snowpack. Most southern aspects nearly bare. Probed around on my descent and didn't find any spots deeper than 75cm. Most of the pack is all facets with some degree of rounding.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is adjacent to avalanche;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
- Site selection due to proximity to Sz. 1 Xe result on 220120 which stepped down to Nov 30 MFcr. - Examining propagation propensity on FC/ recrystallized grains atop Nov 30 MFcr. Results imperfect due to shallower snowpack at test site compared to site of avalanche.
- rounding edges on all FC layers - no temps / temp profile recorded but current temp trend favoring rounding

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Komust ekki í gegnum efsta lag með skóflum. Hefðum þurft stunguskóflu til að komast í gegnum ísinn. Komust í gegn með stönginni og var aðeins mýkra fyrir neðan ca 10 cm. Efsta lag getur verið varasamt ef þurr og laus snjór kemur ofan á sem ekki nær að bindast efsta laginu. Örlítil úrkoma í morgun og er hreyfing á þeim snjó sem féll. Töluverður vindur á svæðinu sem hreyfir nýfennið.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Very thin layer of NSF's at new/ old snow interface at 91cms. (.5mm facets)
Significant wind transportation of new snow on exposed/localized ridgeline locations, from W, NW winds. Observed one recent wind slab avalanche on north aspect of Hyalite Peak.
Obs: JC, DM Below half dome cliff, planar ALP slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Baseline Far Chutes data. Profile dig at elevation where two sides of Murphy's join.

30 cm on interval board since Jan. 10th.
We also dug a little lower on a 35 degree NE aspect at 1950m and found a similar depth but generally weaker snowpack and got 4 x CTE 1 (SC) down 115cm on facets above the Dec. 2nd rain crust.
